awd_titl_txt: CPS: Frontier: Collaborative Research: Compositional, Approximate, and Quantitative Reasoning for Medical Cyber-Physical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This project represents a cross-disciplinary collaborative research effort on developing rigorous, closed-loop approaches for designing, simulating, and verifying medical devices.  The work will open fundamental new approaches for radically accelerating the pace of medical device innovation, especially in the sphere of cardiac-device design. Specific attention will be devoted to developing advanced formal methods-based approaches for analyzing controller designs for safety and effectiveness; and devising methods for expediting regulatory and other third-party reviews of device designs.  The project team includes members with research backgrounds in computer science, electrical engineering, biophysics, and cardiology; the PIs will use a coordinated approach that balances theoretical, experimental and practical concerns to yield results that are intended to transform the practice of device design while also facilitating the translation of new cardiac therapies into practice.

The proposed effort will lead to significant advances in the state of the art for system verification and cardiac therapies based on the use of formal methods and closed-loop control and verification.  The animating vision for the work is to enable the development of a true in silico design methodology for medical devices that can be used to speed the development of new devices and to provide greater assurance that their behaviors match designers' intentions, and to pass regulatory muster more quickly so that they can be used on patients needing their care.  The scientific work being proposed will serve this vision by providing mathematically robust techniques for analyzing and verifying the behavior of medical devices, for modeling and simulating heart dynamics, and for conducting closed-loop verification of proposed therapeutic approaches.  

The acceleration in medical device innovation achievable as a result of the proposed research will also have long-term and sustained societal benefits, as better diagnostic and therapeutic technologies enter into the practice of medicine more quickly.  It will also yield a collection of tools and techniques that will be applicable in the design of other types of devices.  Finally, it will contribute to the development of human resources and the further inclusion of under-represented groups via its extensive education and outreach programs, including intensive workshop experiences for undergraduates.

por.por_cntn:
This project was a cross-disciplinary collaborative effort to develop rigorous, closed-loop approaches for designing, simulating, and verifying medical devices. The work aimed to develop fundamentally new approaches to radically accelerate the pace of medical-device innovation, especially in the sphere of cardiac-device design, the dynamics of which are inherently cyber-physical. The research involved developing advanced formal-methods-based approaches for analyzing controller designs for safety and effectiveness; investigating novel numerical modeling techniques for simulating biological processes to be controlled by medical devices; and investigating methods for expediting regulatory and other third-party reviews of device designs.

The goal of this work is to accelerate medical-device innovation, such as by enabling better diagnostic and therapeutic technologies, which can enter into the practice more quickly than is typical today. To this end, the project created a collection of tools and techniques applicable in the design of medical systems and devices. Finally, the project contributed to the development of human resources and the further inclusion of under-represented groups via its extensive education and outreach programs, including intensive workshop experiences for undergraduates.

Throughout the project, the team developed formal languages and tools relevant to medical use cases. This included operational semantics for a UML activities diagram language, technique for simplifying sets of invariants inferred using so-called association rule mining, and a technique for determining when cardiac cells are undergoing electrical alternans (a condition in which heartbeats alternate between "strong" and "weak").  Alternans is correlated with certain severe physical ailments, including stroke.  Currently, alternans is detected manually via inspections of ECG readings, this specification however opens the door for automated detection of alternans.

With a European visiting researcher, the team developed a model-checking algorithm for classes of hybrid automata against very expressive specifications formulated in the modal mu-calculus. The approach is based on proof search, which has proved very effective in other settings.

The project also developed an automated approach for inferring system invariants from test data.  The motivation for this work was to automate the generation of formal specifications from systems as a means of enabling better system documentation and understanding.  The approach combines the use of data mining with automated system testing and has been applied to automotive systems and medical pacemaker systems. Such invariants provide high-level insight into model behavior and are useful for model comprehension as well as for generating formal specifications for such models.  The methodology that was developed used data-mining techniques, combined with automated test-case generation and model instrumentation, to extract proposed invariants and double-check them.

The team developed techniques for solving the so-called query-checking problem for linear temporal logic (LTL) and finite-length data streams. That is, given a set of data streams and a finite LTL formula with a missing subformula, solve for the missing subformula such that overall solved formula satisfies all data streams. Identifying such solutions can provide allow one  to translate reasoning about a system's executions back to insight about system behavior.  The approach utilizes a novel automata-theoretic representation of the problem which was found to yield a clear analysis of the problem.

The team developed generic on-the-fly techniques for model-checking hybrid system against specifications given in an expressive temporal logic, the timed modal mu-calculus. This project developed efficient, practically applicable model checkers for these classes that are based on proof search, and which are "on-the-fly" in the sense that they only generate information from the model and property necessary to answer the model- checking question.

The team studied foundational compositional theories for non- discrete-time systems. Earlier work had shown that a class of potentially continuous trees, called Generalized Synchronization Trees (GSTs), are a useful foundational model for such systems, and that notions of bisimulation, a semantic equivalence, can be given. The team applied these results in the setting of the so-called behavioral approach to control-system modeling. This work showed that GSTs can be generated from behavioral-approach representations in such a way that the notions of bisimulation between the two theories coincide. The team also showed how notions of system composition developed outside the behavioral approach can now be imported into the theory in a way that ensures bisimulation is a congruence.

The team also studied opacity for linear systems. Roughly speaking, a system is opaque to an external observer if the observer cannot infer secret information within the system by watching its external behavior. Project team members have lifted these notions to several different settings involving linear (so, continuous-state) systems, based on the capabilities of observers (are they centralized or distributed?) and the system (are the systems time invariant? Are they switched?) and have developed algorithms for computing opacity information in these settings.
